decision: Crew are privileged in trust conflicts.
rationale: Crew are the mobile, vulnerable party. Yachts have institutional power. Asymmetric protection prevents the system from becoming another tool for employer control.
notes: Applies to trust asymmetry, not monetisation sequencing.

decision: No star ratings or open free-text reviews.
rationale: Star ratings create false precision. Free-text reviews create coercion dynamics and legal exposure. Both invite gaming.

decision: Never monetise influence over trust outcomes.
rationale: If trust can be bought, trust is worthless. The entire value proposition collapses.

topic: Crew pay first, yachts pay later
decision: Monetisation sequence: crew subscription revenue must stabilise before any yacht-side payments.
rationale: Whoever pays first has implicit power. If yachts pay first, the system optimises for yacht satisfaction over crew truth.

decision: Endorsement retractions are never visible in UI. Backend only.
rationale: Visible retractions create scarlet letter effects. The person who retracted may have legitimate reasons. Viewers assume the worst.
notes: Retraction frequency affects endorser weighting in backend. Feeds into Phase 2 trust calculations.

decision: Renamed or duplicate yachts remain separate entities in Phase 1. No merge functionality.
rationale: Premature merging creates irreversible trust errors. Fragmentation is tolerable; incorrect consolidation is not.
notes: Phase 2+ may introduce merge proposals with quorum approval.

decision: Identity is free infrastructure; presentation is paid and cosmetic only.
rationale: Free identity removes barriers to graph formation. Paid presentation funds operations without corrupting trust.

decision: Introduce yacht entities as verification infrastructure in Phase 1.
rationale: Yacht attachment is the gating mechanism for endorsements. Without this, endorsements are meaningless.

decision: Endorsements require shared yacht attachment. Contacts alone do not permit endorsements.
rationale: Endorsements must be grounded in verifiable shared experience. Social contacts are not evidence of professional competence.

decision: Endorsements contain both structured metadata and free-text. One endorsement per engagement per yacht.
rationale: Structure enables future analysis. Free-text enables nuance. One-per-engagement prevents inflation.
notes: Editing allowed. Deletion allowed but tracked in backend.

decision: Zero endorsements is not a negative signal. The system never labels absence as meaningful.
rationale: Early users and private people should not be penalised. Only contradicted endorsements create negative weight.
notes: Role-relative context may be introduced in Phase 2 without scoring.

decision: Single config flag to switch from public signup to invite-only. PM can pause first, explain after if founder unavailable.
rationale: Reversing a pause is easy. Reversing trust damage is not.

decision: Forbidden: any UI that auto-summarises endorsement density ('well endorsed', 'lightly endorsed', etc.).
rationale: Auto-summaries collapse nuance into judgment. They quietly kill the 'absence is neutral' principle.

decision: PDF snapshot/export is free identity infrastructure. Never monetised.
rationale: PDF export is core to portable identity. Monetising it would gate a fundamental capability behind payment.
notes: Paid scope is limited to templates, layout polish, and watermark removal.

decision: Moderation decisions (fake accounts, attachment confirmation) resolved by community vote, not admin judgment.
rationale: System-mediated moderation grounded in shared employment scales better and resists single points of failure. Admin intervention is last resort.

decision: Verified status grants expanded moderation power. Earned via seed set, endorsements from verified users, tenure+density, or paid subscription.
rationale: Prevents sock puppet networks from gaining moderation power through self-endorsement. Only users vouched for by known-good users can confirm attachments or vote in expanded pools.

decision: Yachts become 'established' after 60 days AND reaching crew threshold. Established yachts require attachment confirmation from verified users.
rationale: Balances open graph formation (fresh yachts) with protection against late-stage infiltration (established yachts).
notes: Crew threshold varies by yacht size. See yl_moderation.vNext.md Section 2.

decision: 67% supermajority for early resolution, simple majority after 7 days, minimum 3 votes required. Ossified accounts require 80%.
rationale: Supermajority prevents marginal removals. Minimum vote threshold prevents 1v1 disputes. Ossification protects established legitimate users.
notes: Accused cannot vote. See yl_moderation.vNext.md Sections 5-6.

decision: Users with overlapping attachment can signal agree/disagree on endorsements. Display only in Phase 1, feeds trust weight in Phase 2+.
rationale: Lightweight social proof without removal power. Allows community to express opinion without triggering moderation.
notes: Signals alone never remove an endorsement. See yl_moderation.vNext.md Section 7.

decision: Receiving many endorsements is not suspicious and is never rate-limited or flagged.
rationale: Senior crew with long careers can plausibly receive many endorsements in a short period. Only endorsements given may ever be constrained.

decision: Users can upload existing CV (PDF/DOCX) to auto-populate profile fields via LLM extraction. Part of free identity layer.
rationale: Reduces onboarding friction. Crew already have CVs — don't make them re-type. Directly supports time-to-first-endorsement tripwire (<30 days median). Competitor parity (yacht.ee has this).
notes: Not verification — extracted data is still self-reported. Implementation: Claude API. Cost target <€0.05/parse. Fallback to manual entry on failure.

decision: Users with full profiles can post jobs for free. Other users can apply with their profile. Graph proximity (mutual colleagues/IRL connections, shared yachts) is visible to both parties. No payment, no algorithmic matching, no employer-only accounts.
rationale: Hiring incentives only corrupt trust when employers pay. When both parties are nodes in the trust graph with visible profiles and reputations, incentives align — both want accurate signals. Captains are crew too. This strengthens the value prop by making the graph immediately useful at the highest-stakes moment (hiring).
notes: Replaces 'Not a job marketplace' non-goal with 'Not an employer-pays hiring platform'. Key constraints: no paid listings, no placement fees, no recruiter tools, poster must have full profile. Jobs are a use case for the graph, not a separate product.

decision: Crew Pro (€12/month) includes database search, extended availability reach, cert expiry alerts, profile analytics, and increased job post limits.
rationale: Search is recruiter behavior — if you're searching the database to find candidates, you're recruiting, so pay for it. Pro becomes valuable for captains/HODs who hire, while free tier remains useful for junior crew building profiles.
notes: Free: 1 job post/month, network-only availability. Pro: 3 job posts/month, 2nd-degree availability reach, full analytics.

decision: Recruiters pay €29/month subscription plus credits (€75-1200 bundles) to access crew search. Credits unlock profile name and contact details from search results. Direct profile links and graph browsing show full profiles to everyone.
rationale: Monetises recruiter access without corrupting trust. Recruiters get read-only access — they cannot influence the graph. Crew profiles remain fully functional for direct sharing (linktr.ee use case preserved).
notes: 1 credit = 1 profile unlock. Unlock is permanent per recruiter-crew pair. Credits expire 1 year from purchase. Recruiters can sort by endorsement count — gating rule prevents gaming.

decision: Profile visibility varies by access method. Direct link/QR shows full profile including contact details. Search results show locked profiles — name and contact details require payment (Pro for crew, credits for recruiters).
rationale: Preserves crew's ability to use profile as public linktr.ee while creating recruiter paywall on efficient discovery. Manual graph browsing remains open but doesn't scale for harvesting.
notes: Graph browsing (click yacht → see crew) shows full profiles. This is intentional — it's slow and doesn't support filtering/sorting. Search is the efficient path; that's what's monetised.

decision: Recruiters can sort search results by endorsement count. This rewards active crew who use the platform.
rationale: Endorsements require shared yacht attachment (D-009), so they cannot be gamed through fake accounts or endorsement trading. More endorsements = more real colleagues vouching = exactly what recruiters should want to see.
notes: Display 'X endorsements from Y people across Z yachts' for richer signal. Endorsement begging may occur but begged endorsements are still from real coworkers with visible text.

decision: Crew opt into recruiter/search pool via availability toggle. Expires after 7 days, must re-toggle. Crew control contact method visibility.
rationale: Active opt-in protects crew from unwanted contact. Weekly expiry prevents stale 'available' crew getting spammed. Crew remain in control.
notes: Reminder sent at day 6. Crew can hide from recruiters entirely while remaining visible to other crew.

decision: Graph edges are created only by shared employment (colleagues) or verified in-person encounters (IRL connections).
rationale: The graph must represent real-world overlap. Messaging alone is not evidence of professional proximity.

decision: Contacts exist for messaging and limited timeline visibility only. They never create trust, endorsements, or graph edges.
rationale: Contacts reduce friction for communication without diluting graph integrity.

decision: A chronological timeline containing posts, interactions, and milestones is permitted when visibility is bounded to a user's network.
rationale: Users maintain real career memory without exposing content to the public or incentivizing global engagement loops.

decision: Timeline ordering is strictly chronological. Trending, boosting, virality, and engagement-weighted ranking are prohibited.
rationale: Algorithmic surfacing creates incentives that corrupt truth-seeking and encourage performative behavior.

decision: In-person encounters are first-class interaction objects requiring mutual confirmation. Interactions may be public or private, with private interactions visible only to participants.
rationale: IRL verification strengthens graph integrity while preserving user control over visibility.

decision: Any participant or tagged user may remove themselves from an interaction or post at any time, removing their association everywhere for other viewers.
rationale: Consent must be revocable to prevent coercion and reduce abuse pressure in real-world encounters.

decision: Yachtielink is open to yachting professionals beyond crew under identical edge-formation and visibility rules, with no privileged trust or visibility.
rationale: The graph should reflect real industry relationships without creating special classes of influence.

topic: Phase 1 hiring constraints are not permanent
decision: Phase 1 hiring surfaces are constrained by design. Future phases may leverage the graph for hiring workflows. No Phase 1 constraint should be interpreted as a permanent prohibition.
rationale: Keeps Phase 1 focused while preserving optionality to deepen graph-based hiring once trust and abuse controls mature.
